definition:
The series $$\begin{aligned}
\sum_{n=1}^\infty\frac{1}{n^s}\end{aligned}$$ converges absolutely for
all $s$ with real part greater than 1.\
[*Proof.*]{} Let $s = \sigma+it$ where $\sigma$ and $t$ are real numbers
and $\sigma > 1$. Then
$$\left|\frac{1}{n^s}\right| = \frac{1}{|e^{s\log{n}}|} = 
\frac{1}{e^{\sigma\log{n}}} = \frac{1}{n^\sigma}.$$ Since the series
$\sum_{n=1}^\infty\frac{1}{n^\sigma}$ converges, by the , for
$\sigma > 1$, we conclude that the series (1) is absolutely convergent
in the half-plane $\sigma > 1$.
